name: Flax Seed Oil
summary: Flax seed oil is a plant-based source of omega-3 fatty acids, particularly alpha-linolenic acid (ALA), used for cardiovascular, metabolic, and general health support.
description: Flax seed oil is extracted from the seeds of the flax plant (Linum usitatissimum). It is one of the richest plant sources of alpha-linolenic acid (ALA), an essential omega-3 fatty acid that the body can partially convert into EPA and DHA, though conversion efficiency is low. Flax seed oil is commonly used to support heart health, reduce inflammation, and improve skin and digestive health. Compared to fish oil, it is often chosen by vegetarians and vegans as a plant-based alternative, though its efficacy in psychiatric or neurological disorders is less established.

monitoring_required: Bleeding risk (at high doses or with anticoagulants)

items: Alternative omega-3 source for vegetarians and vegans

sections.text: Flax seed oil provides alpha-linolenic acid (ALA), an essential omega-3 fatty acid. ALA can be converted in small amounts to EPA and DHA, but the process is inefficient. ALA contributes to anti-inflammatory eicosanoid production, supports lipid metabolism, and helps maintain cell membrane health.

adult.typical: 1000–2000 mg per day of ALA from flax seed oil supplements
adult.note: Higher intakes may be used in dietary contexts; conversion to EPA/DHA is limited.

sections.pediatric: Consult a pediatrician; flaxseed meal is more commonly used in children for fiber.

sections.text: Benefits on general wellness may be gradual; measurable lipid effects may take several months of consistent use.

serious: Increased bleeding risk at high doses

other: Flax seed oil is less effective than fish oil for raising EPA and DHA levels.
May increase bleeding risk when combined with anticoagulants or antiplatelets.

sections.pregnancy: Generally considered safe in food amounts; supplement use should be discussed with provider
sections.pediatrics: Ground flax seeds often used for fiber; oil supplements require supervision
sections.geriatrics: Generally safe; useful as a plant-based omega-3 option

sections.text: No tapering required; may discontinue without withdrawal.

items: Flax seed oil is a preferred omega-3 source for vegans and vegetarians.
Conversion of ALA to EPA and DHA is inefficient (~5–10% to EPA, <5% to DHA).
For psychiatric benefits, direct EPA/DHA sources (e.g., fish oil, algal oil) are usually more effective.

items.label: Pawlosky RJ et al. Physiological compartmental analysis of ALA conversion. J Lipid Res. 2001
